Transcription for 1685921

Rydw i'n mynd i'w ddiddordeu i mi. Fy enw i yw Marsha O'Marney a fi yw Ray Evans ym Carowent.
Yn y Carowent ym Mhobl Tyne.
Yn ym Mhobl Tyne a'r 23 o Meir 2019.
Rydw i'n mynd i fod yn fwy o ddiddordeu am eich gweithio ar y traenau a'r gwaer.
Felly, ddiddordeu i chi, Fyndiwr.
Rydw i'n Ray Evans. Rydw i'n nifer yn 1943.
Rydw i'n mynd yn Carowent. Rydw i'n mynd yma ar y 30 oedd.
Rydw i'n gweithredwr locomotif o…
O, yw'r hyn yn ddiddordeu. Rydw i'n gweithredwr ym Mhobl Tyne o 1958.
Yn hynny, fe ddiddordeu i'r gweithredwr ym 1980.
Yn hynny, fe ddiddordeu i'r gweithredwr diesel.
Dydw i ddim yn ddiddordeu'r traenau'r dyfodol oherwydd bod ym Mhobl Tyne oedd anoddol iawn.
Roedd angen i chi gael gwaith ar y bwtau o ddod oedden nhw, yn eich bod.
Ond roeddwn i'n dweud, fe ddiddordeu yn 1980.

Why did he live there? Well he was a single fellow. He had no family we heard of but there was a lot of people lived in the hostel then mind you.
Drivers and firemen and guards. Well this was because they were just pre-married?
Well a lot of them were, it was sort of an interim depot, Severntunnel. We'd have a lot of people and we'd get promotion to Severntunnel from, in them days you had an actual,
well if you had to vacancy come up, you had to go where the vacancy come up. If you was a senior man, if you joined on the 1st of October in say 58,
if there was no man senior to you at Reading, you'd have to go to Reading. Oh really? Yeah, but I was lucky because I avoided it all. Yeah.
But yeah, you'd live in the hostel. I see. They'd hostel you in Reading, and I'd live in a hostel at Reading, whoever was doing the job would live in a hostel at Reading.
So they were actually? So the men were promoted to Severntunnel, there was Aberdame men there, there was Whitland men there, there was Nayland, Pony Pryth, Dye Jones was a Pony Pryth man. Oh they were from all over.
And the hostel would be a place to sleep? Yes, a place to sleep and meals. There was a canteen in there. OK. Yeah, there was quite a few staff in the canteen, Mrs King, Mrs Hunt. They were the cooks? Yeah, they were the cooks and caterers.
So were they local ladies? Yes, Rocket ladies, Mrs Hunt, her husband was a driver, Doug Hunt. Oh gosh. And her son started the same time as me, Edward Hunt. So he went to school together? No, he went to school together, yeah. Edward Hunt was sat next to me at school. Really? Yeah. Oh, so he might have some photographs maybe. He might, well yeah. I tell you, I haven't seen Edward for years. Oh really? He went as a bit of a recluse.
He didn't marry. He lived with his mother. Well his father died on the footplate, but he lived with his mother and then when his mother died he lived in the house and that's where he's gone. I haven't seen nothing of him. So when you say his father died on the footplate, what happened? Yeah, well he died at an heart attack and died at work. Oh dear. Yeah, oh what the hell's that? I don't know when he died. Mike Laws? Yeah, what the nurse said. We'll have to stop talking. Where's the telephone then?
So, so would most railway depots have a hostel? Was it run by the railway company? Yes, yes. Yes. Yeah. He was funded by the Great, well the British Rail as he was then. So would there have been a bar in there? No. No. There was a bar, the staff association was attached to it. Yeah. That's the separate building that was, that was the British Railway staff association.
Yeah. Where you could go for a drink. Yeah, but after work. After work or while you were at work with somebody. I love it because it's so much part of its time, isn't it now? It was, you know, those days were gone.
There was a pub at Bridgewater called the Britannia and that man would put two pints on the wall at the end of the platform and when you stopped at the platform you'd have a pint each and put the empties back and put the money underneath the glasses. Really? Yeah. Oh my goodness. You wouldn't dream of that now. Instant dismissal, wouldn't it? Yeah, because it's zero tolerance now, yeah.
So then you were an engine cleaner. Yes. And then you progressed to a fireman. Fireman. Yeah. Tell me what a fireman is. Well a fireman was a fellow who put the coal on the actual fire and kept the boiler topped up so on and so forth and observed signals when the driver was, you know, occupied with other things.
So you were that man shoveling the coal into the, it looks like a furnace. Yes, the firebox, yeah. Yeah. And that's called the firebox. Yeah. So, I mean, it must have been, what was it like being a fireman?
Well, it was hard work. Yeah. You'd empty, sometimes you'd move four or five tonne of coal in the shaft. Wow. Yeah. Especially if you was going up to London or something like that up line or sometimes you had little engines, you had smaller engines with smaller, we used to call them bunkers.
The bunker was the place they put the coal in. Well then once you'd, if you went, you used to go to Stormsdown, you'd empty the bunker at Stormsdown going from Severntunnel to Stormsdown which was above Pontypridd. Yeah.
And then we used to go all the way up there, all over the valleys. A lot of the rail places are shut now over the Cymru Viaduct, that's dismantled. Yeah. Yeah, and all. When you look at some of these railways on you, then see the photographs of the houses and that, you just can't imagine that you used to work through there.
That's why I'm so interested to speak to you. Yeah. Yeah, we used to work to Ebbw Vale. Did you? Yeah, we used to work regularly to Oakdale Collery, Llanellath, Cymn, what's the name? Cymn, Cymn, oh I can't think of it, Cilenin, Cilenin South, Cilenin North, all in colleries up the Western Valley and Eastern Valley.
So you would collect. We used to go right up the branches fork on the top of Aberdranys. Yeah. All on the. To collecting coal? Coal, coal, yeah, all coal. So that would have been rich Welsh mining industry then? Exactly, yeah. Yeah.
Everywhere, every, well every say two mile was a collerie virtually up the Valley. And the trains went up there bringing the coal down. Correct. But this wasn't just exclusively for the train, you were transporting the coal as well? Yeah, we'd bring it all to Severntunnel. Oh. And then it would get marshalled at Severntunnel. Yeah. And that's what they used to do on the marshalling yards, they'd have a hump, they'd push a train up to the
top of the hump and then they'd let the wagons run. You'd have a pointsman on the top. He'd say, you'd have a marker, he'd pay 28. If it was road number 28, he'd write it on the buffer. So the pointsman upstairs would look at the buffer and say that wagon's got to go in 28. So he'd set the road up for 28. Next wagon is number 7. Set the road up for 7. And they'd all go down different roads.
Because I heard it was huge the marshalling yards. It was, yeah. It was 28 roads on each side of the. Wow. Yeah. Because it's all gone now. All gone. All gone. That countryside park is the one side, that's the downside that one. Yeah. So it must have been. There was an upside which was all the London traffic etc. so on and so forth. Yeah. And well not necessarily Birmingham, Swindon, all the different valleys down there.
Different place, Temple Mills, Acton, Anwell Bridge, all depots. Morton Cutting used to be another big depot and Morton Cutting which was just the other side of Didcut. Well then they'd send them some of the trains that go rough to Morton Cutting like just London. And then when you got to Morton Cutting they'd sort it out for Taplow, different, all different stations then and then they'd get detached.
So. Because we had a train that we used to call the, it was the Gloucester Pickup. Yeah. Well then we used to start out a serving tunnel. Yeah. We used to work the Sedbrooke. Yeah. With lime for the tunnel. Yeah. Lime. They used to add water to the lime. Lime to the water to thin it out. It was, I don't know what they used to do with it but it was always lime. Then we'd go to pick up a port skewet. Yeah. There was a side of the port skewet, blands, timber side. Yeah.
And then we'd go to Chepstow and shunt to Chepstow. Yeah. But coal in the coal yard and ballast and everything all over the shop. Sometimes you had, when it was race days you used to have race course specials. What do you mean? There was a station here that you could unload the horses. Really? Yeah, all these race horses used to get unloaded at Chepstow. Never heard that before. And they'd walk them then to the race course. Because they didn't have cattle wagons and horse boxes in them days.
That's amazing. Yeah. There was a special Chepstow, Chepstow race course platform they used to call it. And that's long gone. Oh yes. Yes, that's long, long gone. But was that in your time? It was there. I'd ever seen it used. Yeah. But it was there. The platform was there in 5860.
I heard there was a small livestock market at Roggett. Yes, it was. Yeah. Well, there was a big livestock market at Roggett. A big one. Yeah, right opposite the school. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. We used to go over there every Monday. It used to be on a Monday. What, used to go and have a look? Oh yeah, a bit school or something like that. I just have a poke around. Oh, because you were at school there? Yeah, it was at school. They had opposite look. Oh my God. And then on the Mondays we'd always slide over there for a couple of hours, bit school. Did you? Yeah.
Watch all the buying and selling. Yeah. Yeah. So they had, but cattle used to arrive. Oh yeah, they had the cattle specials in Severnton. There was Irish cattle here. Yeah. And then they used to unload them. There's a photo of the cattle bins in that book. Yeah. And then we'd take them down to Moors then to graze them and water them. Where's Moors? Over the Blackbridge. Oh, you wouldn't understand it. Right by the side of the, can I have, can you hand me that book for a second?
Thank you. There's a photograph in here of somewhere with a cattle side in. It must have been such a busy place. Oh yeah, it was unbelievably busy.
It was a car special as well. We used to work them. What's that? Car special before the bridge was opened to Pilnion. Car special? Yeah. They used to load cars up at Severnton. Oh yeah. That was before the bridge was opened. Do you remember that? Yeah, I worked on them, train. You really? Yeah. Yeah, that used to be what they call a banker. What's that mean? Well in 51s it used to assist every train that went through.
The Severnton used to be assisted. What, somebody at the back pushing? No, at the front. Yeah. And then we'd pull them through to Pilnion and then you'd cut off at Pilnion and then you'd push them up to Patchway. Is that because you're going up into Bristol?
No, the trains then, we used to be loose coupled. We never used to couple up to the back of the train. Well then when the train got to the level it could just go. And we'd drop back from the train and then we'd go back to Pilnion to assist the next train.
What, going, you'd reverse out to the tunnel? Yeah, no, we'd go back across, change over the points and come right road back to Pilnion and then we'd wait at Pilnion for another train to come. And then we'd assist that train through the Severnton tunnel in the other direction.
